I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In  April  2004,  during  the  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  Mission,  the 
Government of the Fiji Islands requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance 
(TA) to prepare the Fourth Road Upgrading (Sector) Project (FRUP IV). The ADB Fact-Finding 
Mission visited the Fiji Islands from 30 August to 3 September 2004 and reached an agreement 
with  the  Government  on  the  rationale,  objective,  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services. The TA design is 
based on the Mission's discussions with the Government; observations in the field; and a review 
of data, studies, and reports. The preliminary project framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The Fiji Islands comprise 330 islands scattered over 150,000 square kilometers in the 
South Pacific Ocean. About 100 of the islands are inhabited and about 75% of the population of 
800,000 lives on the main island of Viti Levu, where road transport is important in supporting 
economic development. Road transport is also important on other islands to promote balanced 
development of remote communities.  
 
3.  The majority of the Fiji Islands' infrastructure facilities was built between the mid-1960s 
and mid-1980s, but since that time chronic lack of investment has had an impact on growth 
targets.2 Although the country’s road network is extensive, with over 5,000 kilometers (km) of 
roads (about 20% are sealed), maintenance remains a constant challenge. The Government 
recognizes that roads are vital for intra-island communication to support agriculture, forestry, 
and tourism. A major rehabilitation and upgrading program was initiated in the mid-1980s, 
supported by ADB, World Bank, and several other international agencies. Currently the Third 
[Fiji] Road Upgrading Project (FRUP III)3 is under implementation.  
 
4.  The Public Works Department (PWD) within the Ministry of Works and Energy (MWE) is 
responsible for administration of the national roads network under the Roads Act. Its role is 
principally  road  construction,  maintenance,  and  upgrading  of  both  public  roads  and  roads 
controlled by other ministries. PWD is being restructured (para. 7), and currently employs about 
2,000 people to manage, maintain, and upgrade the road network. 
 
5.  Approximately 78,000 road vehicles are registered in the country; about half are private 
cars. This number has increased at almost 10% per year in recent years as a result of the 
import of secondhand vehicles. Buses and taxis provide extensive services and are entirely 
commercially operated. Heavy road vehicles are limited to 30.8 tons gross weight and 8 ton axle 
loads—low by international standards—but adherence to the restrictions is poor. Vehicle length 
limits of 10 meters limit the use of long articulated vehicles. Trucks are frequently overloaded, 
hauling sugarcane during harvest. Overloaded construction and logging trucks create the most 
damage, contributing to damage pavement and high road accident and fatality rates. 
 
6.  Road transport is administered through the Land Transport Authority (LTA) under the 
Traffic Act.4 LTA undertakes vehicle registration, testing, and driver licensing, as well as traffic

7.  According to National Transport Safety Council statistics, 1,201 motor vehicle fatalities 
were recorded in the past 15 years. Speeding, driving under the influence of alcohol, fatigue, 
and poor eyesight were the main causes. Largely as a result of the Fiji Road Safety Action Plan 
(footnote 4), over the last 8 years the Fiji Islands has been very successful at reducing the rate 
of accidents. The overall vehicle accident rate decreased by 24% during 1995–2003; while 
licensed vehicles increased by over 40%. Fiji Police statistics report that fatal traffic accidents 
have been reduced from about 16.4 deaths per 1,000 vehicles in 1994 to 10 deaths per 1,000 
vehicles in 2003 with a low of 8 in 2002. Much work remains if the National Transport Safety 
Council target of 5 deaths per 1,000 vehicles by the end of 2005 is to be met. 
 
8.  FRUP III (footnote 4) is providing financing for civil works for upgrading about 100 km of 
gravel roads selected from 19 roads identified, rehabilitation and strengthening of about 80 km 
of  existing  sealed  roads,  civil  works  for  road  safety  improvements,  specialized  road 
maintenance and laboratory equipment, and consulting services. The attached TA is providing 
(i) policy and institutional reform by establishing and supporting LTA, and devolving PWD roads 
to  a  statutory  commercial  authority;  (ii)  enhanced  capacity  to  manage  road  assets  by 
establishing a road asset management system; and (iii) support of phase II of the Fiji Road 
Safety Action Plan. The Government plans to continue these activities as outlined in the 20-year 
program of the National Transport Sector Plan (NTSP),5 which was reviewed and updated in 
2004. Progress on all components under FRUP III has been satisfactory except for a major 
international competitive bidding contract to upgrade 50 km of the Kings-Lodoni Road, which is 
unlikely to be completed before scheduled loan closing on 31 December 2005.6 
 
9.  Under the Government's Public Sector Reform Program, MWE initiated a process of 
significant reform to rationalize and commercialize PWD operations in line with the NTSP. This 
process is being undertaken in three phases (i) creating the separate Department of National 
Roads  (DNR)  to  amalgamate  all  road  functions  within  PWD,  (ii)  establishing  a  Fiji  roads 
authority (FRA) and a road fund, and (iii) undertaking initial operations of the FRA. Phase I of 
the reform is currently being supported under TA attached to FRUP III (footnote 4), and the 
current plans are to establish the FRA by 2006. The Government has requested continuing 
assistance for phase II to prepare for the transition to the FRA.  
 
10.  ADB’s  operational  strategy  for  the  Fiji  Islands  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s 
objectives as embodied in the Public Sector Reform Program and the NTSP. ADB’s strategic 
objectives  include  assistance  to  carry  out  institutional  and  policy  reform  based  on  greater 
market  orientation  and  an  enhanced  role  for  the  private  sector.  Adequate  and  efficient 
infrastructure is a key requirement to facilitate private sector development, economic growth, 
and more equitable distribution of benefits. ADB’s operational strategy identified improvement of 
physical  infrastructure  as  a  priority  area  to  support  the  strategic  objectives,  together  with 
complementary assistance for rural livelihoods and outer island development. Over the medium 
term, ADB will continue to emphasize improvement of the policy environment, and given the 
perennial shortage of skills, will place priority on human resource development and institutional 
strengthening of key sector agencies, coupled with promotion of private sector development.

11.  FRUP IV will finance the Government’s road subsector investment program under the 
NTSP. However, given the delay in FRUP III, the Government does not want the NTSP work 
program to slip and will utilize funds already earmarked for the road subsector to prepare 
subproject feasibility studies and engineering designs for FRUP IV.7 The Government has also 
requested assistance to create an appropriate environment for public-private partnerships to 
finance infrastructure development and operations, and to promote public-private partnerships 
in the transport sector. The TA to prepare FRUP IV, with substantial financial input from the 
Government, will enhance ADB’s longstanding partnership with the Government in developing 
the transport sector, providing balanced regional development, and reducing poverty. 
 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
12.  The  purpose  of  the  TA  is  to  prepare  an  investment  project  to  ensure  that  future 
investment in the road subsector is effective; will contribute to an efficient transport sector as a 
whole; and will support the Government's objectives of balanced regional development, poverty 
reduction, and private sector endeavors, taking account of intermodal considerations. 
 
13.  The TA will prepare a detailed feasibility study for FRUP IV to upgrade approximately 
100 km of priority national and rural roads, and rehabilitate a similar length of roads on the 
islands  of  Taveuni,  Vanua  Levu,  and  Viti  Levu.8  The  Project  will  be  based  on  the 
recommendations of the NTSP, and will consolidate the road safety program supported under 
FRUP II and FRUP III. An indicative list of roads is attached as Appendix 2. The TA will help the 
Government’s  sector  reform  program  create  institutional  arrangements  for  sustainable 
management of the road subsector by reorganizing and commercializing PWD, out-sourcing to 
the private sector, and establishing a road fund; and advise the Government on creating the 
appropriate policy environment for public-private partnerships. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
1.  Part  A:  Prepare  the  Investment  Program  and  Provide  Institutional 
Development 
 
14.  Prepare the Investment Program. This activity will build on the subproject feasibility 
studies and detailed designs for the individual road sections to be undertaken by Government-
financed consultants,9 and prepare a comprehensive feasibility study for FRUP IV for possible 
financing by ADB and other cofinanciers. This study, prepared in accordance with appropriate 
ADB guidelines, will review the current policies, legislation, role, and performance of key road 
transport  stakeholders;  and  prepare  a  detailed  feasibility  study  for  the  Project,  addressing

technical,  financial,  economic,  social,  and  environmental  issues;  determine  appropriate 
procurement and implementation arrangements; and address the cross-cutting issues of poverty 
reduction, gender, and good governance. 
 
15.  Provide Institutional Development. This activity will (i) assess the current status of the 
DNR  and  help  MWE  describe  the  corporate  identity,  role,  responsibilities,  corporate  plan, 
management  structure,  financial  and  management  reporting  systems,  outsourcing 
arrangements and procedures, and staffing requirements of the planned FRA, as well as the 
interrelationships between the FRA, LTA, and the Transport Planning Unit within the Ministry of 
Transport and Civil Aviation; (ii) recommend a road subsector cost-recovery policy and user 
charges for road maintenance funding, including the creation of a road fund; and (iii) prepare the 
legal framework and drafting instructions to establish the FRA. 
 
2.  Part B: Public-Private Partnerships   
 
16.  This activity will (i) assess the capacity and potential of the private sector to participate in 
infrastructure financing, operations, maintenance, and service delivery through build-operate-
transfer and similar type projects; (ii) analyze the institutional, legal, and regulatory framework; 
and  prepare  legal  drafting  instructions  and  identify  policy  needs;  and  (iii)  prepare  sample 
contract documents and processes to enable commercial cofinancing, with particular reference 
to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines and international standards for commercial cofinancing. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is US$950,000 equivalent, comprising US$509,000 in foreign 
exchange and US$441,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance US$600,000 to meet the entire foreign exchange cost of US$509,000 and US$91,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the local 
currency cost of US$350,000 equivalent. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
shown in Appendix 3. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  MWE, the Executing Agency for the TA, will coordinate closely with the Ministry of 
Finance,  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation,  and  National  Planning  Office.  MWE  will 
appoint  the  director,  DNR,  as  counterpart  TA  manager,  who  will  also  be  responsible  for 
coordination between the Government-financed and ADB consultants. A TA steering committee 
will be chaired by the chief executive officer of MWE, and include senior representatives from 
DNR, Fiji Police, LTA, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Public Enterprises, Ministry of Transport 
and Civil Aviation, National Transport Safety Council, Prime Minister’s Office, and other relevant 
agencies.  The  committee  will  meet  monthly  to  provide  technical  oversight  and  review  TA 
progress, and will circulate minutes to the Ministry of Finance and ADB. 
 
19.  Two teams of consultants will carry out the activities under the TA, as described in the 
outline terms of reference in Appendix 4. A consulting firm (Team A) will be recruited and 
engaged  by  ADB  under  its  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  procedures  using  a  biodata 
technical proposal to undertake Part A of the TA: (i) prepare the investment program; and (ii) 
provide institutional development. About 14.5 person-months of international and 6 person-
months of domestic consulting will be required, with experience in transport economics and

5
sector  analysis,  highway  engineering,  road  safety,  environmental  and  social  assessment, 
institutional reform, and legislative drafting. A team of individual consultants (Team B) will be 
recruited and engaged by ADB to undertake Part B of the TA, the study of public-private 
partnerships.  About  5  person-months  of  international  and  3  person-months  of  domestic 
consulting  will  be  required  over  3  months,  with  experience  in  public-private  partnerships, 
infrastructure financing, and legislative drafting.  
 
20.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants by the Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. Equipment will be procured by 
the consultants in accordance with arrangements acceptable to ADB.10 The TA will be carried 
out over 6 months, from March to August 2005. 
 
21.  Consultants to be financed under the TA will prepare (i) a full feasibility study of the 
proposed  FRUP  IV  investment  program,  with  appendixes  covering  the  technical,  financial, 
economic, poverty, social, and environmental details, in accordance with ADB guidelines (Team 
A); (ii) corporate and business plans and road subsector funding arrangements for the proposed 
FRA, training programs, and drafting instructions for appropriate enabling legislation (Team A); 
and (iii) a description of the financing framework for private-public partnerships, and sample 
documentation and drafting instructions for legislation to facilitate such partnerships (Team B). 
Each team will submit a brief inception report, an interim report at the midterm point, a draft final 
report, and a final report. The Government and ADB will review the draft inception, interim, and 
final reports at tripartite meetings to be held in the Fiji Islands with the consultants to review the 
consultants’ findings and recommendations. The consultants will submit their final reports within 
1 month of receipt of the comments.  
 
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of US$600,000 on a grant basis 
to the Government of the Fiji Islandsfor preparing the Fourth Road Upgrading (Sector) Project, 
 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
A.  Part  A:  Prepare  the  Proposed  Fourth  Road  Upgrading  Project  (FRUP  IV)  and 
Provide Institutional Development 
 
1.  Consulting Services. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit a consulting firm 
(Team A) under its quality- and cost-based selection procedures to undertake Part A of the 
technical assistance (TA). About 14.5 person-months of international and 6 person-months 
domestic consulting input will be required over 6 months. The consultants will have experience 
in transport economics and sector analysis, highway engineering, road safety, environmental 
and social assessment, institutional reform, and legislative drafting. 
 
2.  Prepare the Investment Program. This activity will prepare the overall feasibility report 
for the proposed Project in accordance with ADB guidelines, and cover technical, economic and 
financial, and social and environmental aspects for a project acceptable for possible financing 
by ADB or other external financers. In particular, the consultants will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  Review the current policies, legislation, and practices in the road subsector, and 
the role and performance of key road transport agencies, including the Ministry of 
Transport and Civil Aviation and its Transport Planning Unit, Ministry of Works 
and Energy (MWE), Public Works Department (PWD), Land Transport Authority 
(LTA),  and  leading  transport  sector  stakeholders.  Assess  the  achievements 
under TA attached to the Third Fiji Road Upgrading Project for Road Sector 
Reform and Safety Improvements.  
(ii)  Review  proposed  alternative  alignments,  capacity  enhancement  works,  and 
alternative modes of transport on congested road sections and in particular the 
Suva-Nausori  and  Sigatoka-Lautoka  corridors,  taking  into  account  proposed 
alternative  alignments,  environmental  and  social  implications,  ongoing  and 
planned  private  and  commercial  development  within  the  corridor,  impending 
completion of the Rewa Bridge, and proposals for upgrading the Nausori Airport. 
Prepare preliminary cost estimates for each design option, and assess potential 
funding modalities, including prospects for commercial cofinancing. 
(iii)  Clearly  and  succinctly  describe  the  objectives  of  the  proposed  Project,  and 
provide a detailed description of proposed scope; develop and refine the project 
framework, describing the goals, objectives, and expected outcomes; outputs 
and inputs, including monitorable, quantifiable, and time-bound indicators and 
targets, responsibilities, risks, and assumptions.  
(iv)  Appraise  the  output  resulting  from  the  Government-financed  consultants 
engaged to prepare subproject feasibility studies and designs, and formulate an 
investment  program  suitable  for  funding  by  ADB  or  other  cofinanciers, 
recommending  packaging  of  subprojects  into  appropriate  sizes  suitable  for 
procurement  through  international  competitive  bidding  and  local  competitive 
bidding procedures or other appropriate forms of procurement.  
(v)  Prepare detailed cost estimates in accordance with ADB’s requirements, and a 
detailed financing plan, including proposed ADB, private sector, and counterpart 
financing, and beneficiary contributions where appropriate.

3.  Provide  Institutional  Development.  Recognizing  MWE's  ongoing  program  to 
commercialize PWD operations in line with the National Transport Sector Plan and the Public 
Sector Reform Program, this activity will provide assistance to PWD to consolidate the activities 
under the recently formed Department of National Roads (DNR) and prepare DNR for its 
transition to a road authority, planned for 2006. Initial activities conducted under Phase I of the 
reform were to separate the functions of PWD to create a separate DNR. The activity under the 
TA will concentrate on phase II (establishment of the Fiji road authority [FRA]) and preparation 
of phase III (initial operations of the FRA). The consultants will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare the corporate identity, role, and responsibilities of the planned FRA, as 
well  as  proposed  interrelationships  between  FRA,  LTA  and  the  Transport 
Planning Unit within the Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation. In particular, 
make recommendations on combining the LTA and FRA into a single authority. 
(ii)  Propose  management  arrangements,  organizational  structures,  and  staffing 
requirements for the FRA, including the board and executive structure; financial, 
human, and asset management systems; reporting relationships and terms of 
reference; business plans; and budgeting procedures. 
(iii)  Review available studies, in particular the outcome of the TA Road Sector Cost 
Recovery Improvement,1 and conduct consultations with key stakeholders within 
the Government and the road transport sector to make recommendations for a 
road subsector cost recovery policy and user charges for road maintenance 
funding, including the creation of a sustainable road fund. 
(iv)  Review the Road and LTA acts to identify opportunities to streamline agency 
roles and responsibilities, and assist MWE to prepare the legal framework and 
drafting instructions to establish the FRA. 
(v)  Determine  the  appropriate  mix  of  in-house  and  commercially  out-sourced 
services to support the efficient and sustainable management of road transport 
infrastructure,  particularly  performance-based  contracting;  and  develop 
standards,  documentation,  procedures,  organizational  structures,  and 
management information systems to support these activities. 
(vi)  Prepare a training program and provide initial training activities for DNR staff to 
effectively administer road construction contracts and manage the road network 
under the new organizational structure; in particular, provide technical training to 
senior  staff  on  road  network  management,  construction  and  maintenance

B.  Part B: Public-Private Partnerships 
 
6.  Consulting Services. A team of individual consultants (Team B) will be recruited and 
engaged by ADB. About 5 person-months of international and 3 person-months of domestic 
consulting input will be required over 3 months, which will encompass experience in public-
private partnerships, infrastructure financing, and legislative drafting.  
 
7.  Public-Private Partnerships. Recognizing the Government's desire to promote public-
private partnerships in the provision of transport infrastructure services and similar services in 
other sectors, the consultants will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Recognizing economies of scale, review the capacity of the public and private 
sector, including institutional capacities of public agencies, external and domestic 
financiers,  strategic  partners,  and  transport  operators  to  participate  in 
infrastructure financing and operation, maintenance and service delivery, and 
assess the potential of the public and private sectors to participate in schemes 
such  as  build-operate-transfer  and  build-operate-own.  Include  all  options  of 
public and private ownership, ranging from contracted services and leasing of 
assets  to  sale  of  asset/shares  and  build-operate-own  (but  not  including 
divestiture)  to  ensure  the  best  alternatives  can  be  selected  for  further 
consideration. 
(ii)  Undertake an institutional and legal analysis to determine possible impediments 
or  gaps  in  the  institutional,  legal,  and  regulatory  frameworks;  make 
recommendations,  prepare  legal  drafting  instructions,  and  identify  policy 
initiatives to develop appropriate institutional arrangements, overcome legal or

regulatory  impediments  and  gaps,  and  brief  key  decision-makers  and 
stakeholders.  
(iii)  Identify institutional arrangements to allow public sector agencies to prioritize, 
provide resources for, and approve transactions; identify opportunities to adjust 
the contracting process from input- to output-based contracting to allow more 
flexible  and  cost-effective  approaches  to  risk  management;  recommend 
appropriate procurement processes; recommend how to establish a clear legal 
structure  and  legal  due  diligence  to  address  contractual  issues;  develop 
guidelines to define the extent of public-private partnerships implementation and 
project scope; assess the economic and political risks for the participants; and 
establish  mechanisms  to  monitor  and  gauge  the  success  of  public-private 
partnerships, particularly in terms of profitability and financial sustainability. 
(iv)  Assess  the  regulatory  institutions  to  determine  the  functional  responsibilities

checks  and  balances  in  creating  codependency,  transparency,  fairness, 
proportionality in contracts; establish effective user-charge policies to safeguard 
consumer interests; and establish criteria to ensure the equitable distribution of 
risks and responsibilities between involved parties. 
(v)  Recognizing  that  public-private  partnerships  will  not  be  limited  to  roads  or 
transport  activities,  develop  a  long  list  of  potential  public-private    projects.

TA.
